chapter.htmlHeader: What should alert me to child maltreatment?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Note: while general practitioners (GPs) are not responsible for investigating child abuse and neglect, they have a responsibility for raising concerns, sharing information, and working together with statutory agencies to contribute to child protection processes. GPs have a statutory duty to cooperate with other agencies to improve the well-being of children, and also have a duty to refer children to social care (in England under Sections 17 and 47 of the Children Act 1989) when indicated, and may receive requests from social workers, the police, and occasionally the NSPCC, to share information about a child or family. 

  • When assessing the possibility of child maltreatment, be aware of risk factors that have been linked to abuse and neglect and the barriers to recognition of child maltreatment.
  • Features that should be noted include the child/young person's appearance, behaviour or demeanour, and interaction with the parent or carer. Also assess for any alerting features in the child/young person's history, including frequency of attendance at primary and secondary care, any previous contact with social services, and obtain relevant information on other adults and children in the home.
  • Be open-minded when considering the possible cause of an injury or other sign. In order to consider non-abusive causes for any presenting features, ask questions about:
    • Perinatal history — birth-related trauma, history of prematurity.
    • Medication and other possible iatrogenic causes.
    • Past medical history of fractures or bleeding disorders.
    • Family history of clotting disorders, metabolic disease, fractures, blue sclera, and deafness (to exclude osteogenesis imperfecta).
  • Signs that may alert a clinician to the possibility of child maltreatment can include:
    • Frequent attendance or unusual patterns of presentation to healthcare services, often due to injuries/features that may suggest physical or sexual abuse, neglect, or less commonly, fabricated or induced illness. For further information, see the sections on physical abuse, sexual abuse, neglect, and fabricated or induced illness.
    • Inappropriately explained poor school attendance — that has no justification on health grounds and home education is not being provided.
    • Refusal by the parent or carer to allow a child or young person to speak to a healthcare professional on their own when it is necessary for the assessment of the child or young person.
    • Unusual or marked changes in the child's behaviour or emotional state, that are unexpected for their age and developmental stage, and not explained by a medical condition, neurodevelopment disorder, or stressful situation (outwith the possible maltreatment).  These can include:
      • Recurrent nightmares containing similar themes.
      • Self-harming — including cutting, scratching, picking, biting or tearing skin to cause injury, pulling out hair or eyelashes and deliberately taking prescribed or non-prescribed drugs at higher than therapeutic doses.
      • Scavenging, stealing, hoarding, or hiding food with no medical explanation (such as Prader–Willi syndrome).
      • Bedwetting or encopresis — particularly where parents or carers are seen or reported to punish a child for wetting or soiling despite professional advice that the symptom is involuntary.
      • Running away.
      • Marked oppositional or aggressive behaviour.
      • Substance or alcohol misuse, eating disorders, suicidal behaviours, bullying or being bullied.
      • Habitual body rocking.
      • Dissociation behaviour — this is a trance state which is involuntary and is not explained as typical daydreaming, seizures, or deliberate avoidance of interaction.
      • Repeated, extreme or sustained anger, frustration (expressed as a temper tantrum in a school-aged child), or distress expressed as inconsolable crying.
      • Emotional withdrawal.
      • Responding to a health examination or assessment in an unusual, unexpected or developmentally inappropriate way (for example, extreme passivity, resistance, or refusal).
      • Fearfulness.
      • Over-friendliness with strangers.
      • Excessive clinginess.
      • Low self-esteem.
      • Persistent attention seeking behaviour or excessive 'good' behaviour to prevent parental/carer disapproval.
      • Failing to seek or accept comfort or affection from an appropriate person.
      • Coercive controlling behaviour towards parents or carers.
      • Lack of ability to understand and recognise emotions.
      • Excessive comforting behaviours in very young children when witnessing parental or carer distress.
      • Poorer than expected language abilities for their overall development in a child aged under 12 years, particularly in their ability to express their thoughts, wants, and needs.
      • Indiscriminate, precocious, or coercive sexual behaviour in a young person.
    • Evidence of sexual activity in a child/young person, for example, a sexually transmitted infection, or pregnancy in an underage female. For further information, see the section on sexual abuse.
    • Persistent harmful behaviour towards the child/young person from the parent/carer suggestive of emotional abuse. Examples include:
      • Negativity or hostility.
      • Rejection or scapegoating. 
      • Developmentally inappropriate expectations of or interactions with a child, including inappropriate threats or methods of discipline.
      • Exposure to frightening or traumatic experiences.
      • Using the child for the fulfilment of the adult's needs (for example, in marital disputes).
      • Failure to promote the child's appropriate socialisation (for example, involving children in unlawful activities, isolation, not providing stimulation or education).
      • Emotional unavailability and unresponsiveness from the parent or carer towards a child or young person and in particular towards an infant.
    • Evidence of neglect — that is, persistent failure to meet the child or young person's basic physical or psychological needs that is likely to result in the serious impairment of their health or development, including non-attendance at hospital appointments or failure to administer essential prescribed medication. For further information, see the section on neglect.
    • If child maltreatment is suspected (i.e. there is a serious level of concern but no proof) or considered (i.e. maltreatment may be a differential diagnosis for an alerting feature), seek an explanation for any injury or presentation from both the parent or carer and the child or young person in an open and non-judgemental manner. An unsuitable explanantion is one that is considered to be implausible, inadequate, or inconsistent with the child or young person's presentation, normal activities, existing medical condition, age or developmental stage. Accounts may differ between the child/young person and their parent/carer, between parents or carers, and/or over time. An explanation based on cultural practice should not justify hurting a child or young person.
    • In all conversations with children and young people where there are concerns about child abuse and neglect: 
      • Make sure that conversations take place somewhere private and where the child or young person feels comfortable. Work at the child or young person's pace. Be sensitive and empathic.
      • Tailor communication to their age and developmental stage, any disabilities, such as learning disabilities, communication needs, for example by using communication aids or providing an interpreter (ensure the interpreter is not a family member), and any sensory issues.
      • Be sensitive to any religious or cultural beliefs.
      • Use plain language and explain any technical terms.
      • Explore your concerns in a non-leading way, for example by using open questions. Avoid causing possible prejudice to any formal investigation during early conversations about child abuse and neglect with children and young people by following guidance in the Ministry of Justice's Achieving the best evidence in criminal proceedings.
      • Explain confidentiality when you might need to share specific information, and with whom — see the section on management for further details.
      • Listen actively, find out their views and wishes.
      • Check your understanding of what the child has told you.
      • Give them opportunities to stop the conversation or leave the room, and follow up if this does happen.
      • Explain what will happen next and when.
      • Be aware that when children and young people communicate their abuse or neglect, it may refer to non-recent events.
  • Note: A GP should also consider whether an adult patient (including a pregnant woman) is displaying features and/or has relevant risk factors that may suggest they pose a risk to children or young people (in the case of a pregnant woman, their child after birth), and act accordingly — see the section on management for further details.

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Managing a child or young person where maltreatment is suspected or considered

subChapters.htmlHeader: Barriers to recognition
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The following have been identified as possible barriers to recognizing and responding to child maltreatment:

  • The relationship between the health professional and patient — this relationship is based on trust and mutual respect. Healthcare professionals might fear that raising concerns could upset and anger the family and therefore damage this relationship. They may also fear for their own professional and personal safety.
  • Poor communication between health professionals — information from a number of different sources often needs to be shared to properly understand the problem. Concerns about confidentiality, consent, and data protection may impair the sharing of this information.
  • Uncertainty about local procedures or contacts.
  • Concentrating more on the parents than the child — parents can easily overshadow the child removing the focus of attention away from the child.
  • Unwillingness to recognize a problem — because of the demands on time and difficulty associated with child protection issues.
  • Overlooking behavioural or emotional changes associated with child maltreatment.
  • Underestimating the problem — this includes underestimating the effect of alcohol, drug misuse, parental mental health problems, or domestic violence on children.
  • Abusers covering up the problem — for example by not seeking medical help, seeking medical help for the child at different locations, or providing plausible explanations for the presenting features of child maltreatment.
  • Accepting the cause of the problem — such as tolerance of neglect where there is material deprivation. Neglect is more common where there is poverty, however, poverty is neither a necessary nor a sufficient and acceptable explanation of neglect.
  • Lack of confidence in the system — health professionals may feel that the costs of engaging the child and family in the child protection system are not justified by the benefits, especially if the benefits are perceived as being small.
  • Discomfort with judging someone else's child-rearing practices.
  • Acceptance of different cultural practices as normal even when harmful to the child — for example, a health professional may assume that females are less valued in some cultures and more readily accept neglect of female children.

Be aware that children and young people who are being abused or neglected may find it difficult to tell someone for the first time because:

  • They may have feelings of confusion, shame, guilt and of being stigmatised.
  • They may not recognise their own experiences as abusive or neglectful.
  • They may be being coerced by (or may be attached to) the person or people abusing or neglecting them.
  • They may fear the consequences of telling someone, for example, that no one will believe them, the abuse or neglect might get worse, their family will be split up or excluded by their community, or they will go into care.
  • They may have communication difficulties or may not speak English fluently.
    • Note: boys and young men may be less likely to disclose sexual exploitation than their female counterparts.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The information on recognizing child maltreatment is largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Child abuse and neglect [NICE, 2017b] and Child maltreatment: when to suspect maltreatment in under 18s [NICE, 2017a].

Role of general practitioners, barriers to recognition

  • The information on the role of GPs in child protection processes and barriers to recognition of maltreatment is partially based on expert opinion in the RCGP and NSPCC Toolkit for General Practice Safeguarding Children and Young People [RCGP and NSPCC, 2014].

Differential diagnosis

  • The advice to consider differential diagnoses for potential signs and symptoms of child maltreatment is based on expert opinion in the General Medical Council (GMC) guideline Protecting children and young people: the responsibilities of all doctors [GMC, 2018].
  • The advice on questions to ask to confirm/rule out potential non-abusive causes is based on expert opinion in the BMJ Best Practice guideline Child abuse [BMJ Best Practice, 2018].
